name: Dr Wong Changi
institution: Swinburne University of Technology Sarawak Campus
location: Jalan Simpang Tiga 93350 Kuching, Sarawak, Malaysia
bio: Changi’s research career has concentrated on environmental biogeochemistry and microplastics. He aims to deepen the understanding of microplastic pollution in Southeast Asian coastal environments and its solutions. His work extensively involves studying biogeochemical cycles and the impacts of microplastics on these systems. He holds a PhD in Biology and continues his postdoctoral research at Swinburne University of Technology Sarawak Campus, where he also teaches part-time. His expertise includes microbiology, molecular biology techniques such as DNA extraction and PCR, and plant tissue culture. Changi has engaged in community outreach programs aimed at raising awareness and reducing plastic waste through recycling and upcycling initiatives. His research and educational efforts underscore his commitment to tackling environmental issues, especially related to plastic pollution and its broader ecological impacts.

name: Dr Jenny Choo
role: Joint Postdoctoral Researcher (CSIRO – Plymouth Marine Laboratory)
institution: Swinburne University of Technology, Sarawak campus
location: Jalan Simpang Tiga, 93350, Kuching, Sarawak, Malaysia
bio: Jenny’s research has spanned from microbiology-based experiments to environmental science activities. Her recent research focuses on applying digital-based solutions, such as the application of the Open Data Cube (ODC) platform, to study the dynamical changes of water and land through satellite observations and analysis. Collaborating with experts from CSIRO, Australia, she gains experience in utilizing earth observation tools to process and analyze large volumes of satellite datasets, aimed at better management of water and land changes. Jenny is also involved in the Aquawatch mission by CSIRO to establish a ground-to-space water quality monitoring system in Sarawak. Her computing and programming skills include Python, R language, and machine learning approaches.

name: Johnathan Daniel Maxey
institution: Swinburne University of Technology, Sarawak campus
location: Jalan Simpang Tiga, 93350, Kuching, Sarawak, Malaysia
bio: I was introduced to the field of microbial ecology and nutrient cycling during my master's research and have been involved in projects regarding environmental monitoring, nutrient cycling, benthic and pelagic microbial ecology for the US Department of Defence, the Tasmanian Salmon Growers Association, and Sanford, among others. I studied the interaction of dissolved oxygen, nitrous oxide, and aquaculture as part of my PhD research. My interests lie in gaining an improved understandings of aquaculture environmental interactions, especially regarding biogeochemical impacts and aquaculture site selection.
